comments.text:
Created attachment 558491
Link Checker Application

The attached program will scan domains and create reports on internal and external broken links. The program will create historical point-in-time graphs and reports on the exact pages with the broken links. This will assist in creating a baseline for our broken links and assist with future planning.

Install docs:

cd /usr/local
sudo tar -xzvf /path/to/linkchecker.tar.gz

Install it with:

/usr/local/linkchecker/bin/install.sh

which will prompt for the mysql root password to create the database.

Docs are at:

/usr/local/linkchecker/doc/README

Raymond Etornam can elaborate on the install issues and how the first run went. We will probably have to tweak the code as it was written a few years ago and I also believe that it sees 301/302 redirectors as broken links.

After we get it working with moz.com, we can import all of the production domains list below to get a count for all Mozilla properties:

https://wiki.mozilla.org/Websites/Domain_List/prod

comments.text: Rik: ahh, ok. So the links are invalid on purpose so they set the map location and not conflict with the #map DOM element, right? So, in reality, they are broken links, but are only used by the JS to set the map location. To a spider, they may look broken, but to an end user, it is expected behavior.
